entry.title: Re: Can FBD1 be used for AP posting?
entry.content:
For information, FBD1 is used to create recurring entry documents. It is designed for general ledger postings (e.g., accruals, depreciation, recurring expenses). The recurring entry template is later picked up by F.14 (Program for recurring entries) to generate actual FI documents.

Why your batch input fails because, you are trying to post PK 31 (vendor) and PK 50 (expense). Vendor line items (AP subledger postings) are not supported in FBD1 recurring entry templates. That is why the amount and G/L account fields are missing in the batch input recording ‚Äî the AP line item simply isn‚Äôt captured by FBD1‚Äôs dynpro flow. FBD1 only records G/L accounts, not vendor/customer subledger accounts.

If you want recurring postings involving vendors (AP), use F-02 (general posting) or FB01 for one-time manual postings. For recurring vendor invoices, you should use Recurring Vendor Invoices functionality in MM (Logistics Invoice Verification) or Accounts Payable module. Alternatively, you can set up parked documents or payment requests depending on your business process.

Dears,

Our company is in S4/H environment and now we have a problem with MRP and ATP. Counld anyone helps here to figuire it out?  Appreciates in advance.

Eg the situation is:

(1)Today is 26.01.123;    inventory on hands  = 10EA,  and  I create a Sales order with delivery date = 26.01.31, QTY = 10EA.  By executing ATP,  the schedule line shows confirmed 10 EA on 26.01.31;

(2) Then, I create another sales order with dilivery date = 26.01.23, QTY = 5 EA. Since the available QTY now is zero, so no confirmatino here.

(3) Afert thatÔºå i run th MRP by MD02 by single-levle and expect to a planned order created on 26.01.23. But the MRP result is a planned order on 26.01.31.   In such case ,acturally I can not deliver on-time for the earlier sales order even there was new procurement already created.

entry.title: Tools in Service Transactions
entry.content:
You are a service manager

  • You create a service order to plan a service on customer site. 
  • You identify that this certain service can only be carried out using a specific tool such as a lifting platform.
  • You are wondering how you can use such tools in your service order.

Solution

  • In this blog I am going to explain how you can enable products as tools that can be used in service transactions.

 

Configurations in Customizing

Configurations are to be done that are are prerequisites for creation of products as tools.

Change Material Type FHMI

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Basic Settings -> Material Types -> Define Attributes of Material Types. 
  • You flag the checkbox for material type FHMI with description Production Resource/Tool and open the details.
  • You flag the checkbox Sales in the box User departments. (See screenshot in Figure 1.)  

Figure 1: Change view ‚ÄúMaterial types‚Äù for material type FHMI (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Change Screen Sequences

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Configuring the Material Master -> Define Structure of Data Screens for Each Screen Sequence.
  • In displayed view you select the checkbox for screen sequence 21 with description Std ind.(short) tab pages and double-click on Data screens on the left panel.
  • In displayed view you select the checkbox for screen sequence 21 and screen 17, then you double-click on Subscreens on the left panel.
  • In displayed view you change the program of screen sequence 21, screen 17, and subscreen 4 from SAPLMGD1 to SAPLCRMS4_PRUDUCT_SUBSCREEN. (See screenshot in Figure 2.)  

Figure 2: View Subscreens (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Maintain status for MARA-SRV_DURA and MARA-SRV_DURA_UOM

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
  • In displayed view search for field name MARA-SRV_DURA and double-click on this line so the view Field Groups is opened. In this view change the maintenance status from V to VF. (See screenshot in Figure 3.) 
  • You do the same for field name MARA-SRV_DURA_UOM.

Figure 3: View Field Groups for field name MARA-SRV_DURA (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Hide MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI for material type FHMI

Since the fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI are not relevant for tools used in service transactions, you can hide them for the field reference that is assigned to the material type FHMI.

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
  • You choose a new field selection group for the two fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL (Response Profile) and MARA-SRV_SERWI (Service Profile) for instance you enter 211 as new selection group. 
  • You click on button Field Selection Maintenance at the end of the line so that the field selection group 211 is displayed.
  • Since these two fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI are not relevant for tool items, you can hide them for the field reference that is assigned to the material type FHMI. For instance, you can set the radio button for Hide for field reference HALB that is assigned to the material type FHMI. (See screenshot in Figure 4.)

Figure 4: Example for hiding fields in selection group 211 (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Create a Product for Tools

  • You create a new product for material type FHMI (Production Resource/Tool), for instance SRV_TOOL (Service Tool) for industry sector M (Mechanical engineering).
  • As the configurations are done in customizing, you can maintain data in view Sales: sales org. 2 such as sales organization for instance 1710, distribution channel for instance 10, and item category group SRVT (Service Tool)
  • You can check view Prod.resouces/tools and maintain the work duration for this product.

Figure 5: Product Master view Prod.resources/tools of example product SRV_TOOL (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Controlling Integration

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Integration with Other SAP Components -> Customer Relationship Management -> Settings for Service Processing -> Controlling Integration -> Determine Cost Center and Activity Type for Tool.
  • You assign a cost center and an activity type to the created product SRV_TOOL. (See screenshot in Figure 6.)
  • As for service products, you maintain cost rates for respective cost center and activity type in SAP GUI transaction KP26 or open the following path in SAP Menu: Accounting -> Controlling -> Cost Center Accounting -> Planning ->Activity Output/Prices -> Change.

Figure 6: Example of cost center and activity type assignment to product SRV_TOOL (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Tool Items in Service Transactions

Now let‚Äôs process a tool item in service transactions. You can create a service quotation for a service and a tool that is required for execution of the service. (See screenshot in Figure 7.) 

Figure 7: Example of a service quotation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

The duration for the tool item is derived from product master data, in this example two hours. (See screenshot in Figure 8.) 

Figure 8: Example of a duration of a service quotation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

After accepting, a service order is created as follow-up. Of course, you can create a service order for a service and a tool directly. (See screenshot in Figure 9.) 

Figure 9: Example of a service order tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You enter the actual duration that is used for the tool. In this example three hours, see screenshot in Figure 10.

Figure 10: Example of a service confirmation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You complete the service confirmation. For the service confirmation tool item, a controlling document is created to post actual cost. (See screenshot in Figure 11.) 

Figure 11: Example of a service confirmation (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

The actual duration was passed on as quantity to post the actual cost. You can check the quantity in app Service Actuals when item-based accounting is used. (See screenshot in Figure 12.) 

Figure 12: Service Actuals for a tool item when item-based accounting is used (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Conclusion

Hopefully after reading this blog post, you will have more in-depth knowledge about the enablement of tools and its process in service transactions.

Please don‚Äôt hesitate to raise your questions in Q&A forum of SAP Community or leave your comments below!

For more details, please visit the full product assistance documentation in the SAP Help Portal:

  • Items in Service Orders | SAP Help Portal 
  • Tool Items in Service Transactions | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: What is the most efficient way to create a search string which always hits (only once) in TPAMA?
entry.content:
Hello SAPers,

many times we need in T028P to define a deviating rule from T028G which is independent of the text string (FEBRE table).

So far we are using (^| |?)($|?) but this leads to absurd number of hits and loops within BSPS_PATTERN_SEARCH, which we believe hinders performance with banks statement import.

How have you approached such requirement?

We think that maybe (^)($|?) could do it, but we are unsure as in the simulation it doesn't get any results, but in FEB_BSPROC it seems to work.

Any ideas?

I cannot simply delete the search string in TPAMA, as then it saves the T028P inexistent search strings as inactive.

entry.title: Re: Styling your Custom Frontend like SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Hi @StKollos ,

thanks! That is a very good point and I thought to add it to this post but it could probably be a post for itself üòõ 

We are in those discussions internally but it takes a bit more to officially release such library. You need to dedicate quite some resources to manage an official maintenance and deprecation process. This would limit our internal developments and also for sure bind more resources to this topic permanently. Also we would get less flexible to make breaking changes as we have no control who uses them.

I "believe" in time we might see such a release but I cannot say when. So you can use them but you cannot complain if something needs to be adapted if we change something.

Also from my experience, when you really have a very custom requirement of a customer, it often is better to style the application but have unlimited freedom how you "design" the features and elements to have the biggest impact on the user experience. For this, the CSS is a very good approach. If you need a 100% table style UI, you can use the "custom services". But for sure, there are cool elements like the next best action buttons, the timeline and some more that are just great looking ready components. üôÇ

Note: I am not part of the product organizations and have no direct insights, all the above is more or less my common sense / general knowledge regarding making the libary public. üôÇ

Appreciating your thoughts!

Thanks

Jens

entry.title: Settlement Error in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Cost Element Not Assigned to Source Structure
entry.content:
Settlement Error in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Cost Element Not Assigned to Source Structure

**Body:**

Hello SAP Community,

I'm encountering an error when settling an investment project (F4568) in **SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition**.

**Error Message:**
```
No source assignment found for cost element 61003000

Diagnosis:
The sender bears the YS source structure and was debited with costs from the 61003000 cost element. This cost element is not assigned to any source assignment in the A000 controlling area of the YS source structure.

Procedure:
Maintain the YS source structure.
```

**Environment:**
- SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
- Controlling Area: A000
- Cost Element: 61003000 (Primary cost element, Category 1 - Travel Expense Hotel)
- Project Type: Investment Project (AUC)
- Transaction: Settlement (F4568)

**What I've Found:**
1. In "Analysis of Value Category Assignments" app, cost element 61003000 appears in the "Not assigned" list
2. I tried to assign it to a Value Category but cannot edit from this screen
3. Allocation Structure YT (PS Project Settlement) uses Cost Element Group "100_CE" which doesn't exist in the system

**My Question:**
Could someone provide a **step-by-step solution** with specific **app names and IDs** to resolve this error in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

Please note: I need solutions specific to **Public Cloud only** - on-premise transaction codes (like OKEU, KAH2) are not applicable.

Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: Re: Order to Cash Process
entry.content:
Yes quite possible. Follow the below steps

1. Sales Order Creation
Sales order is created in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Sales. Shipping condition ‚ÄúTM ‚Äì Int. Planning‚Äù triggers Transportation Management (TM) integration for freight planning and execution.

2. Outbound Delivery
Delivery document is generated from the sales order. TM provides freight units and planning results. Delivery is released for warehouse processing.

3. Post Goods Issue (PGI)
At PGI, inventory is credited and Goods-In-Transit (GIT) is debited. This ensures stock is removed from inventory but not yet recognized as COGS until POD confirmation.

4. Proof of Delivery (POD)
POD functionality is available in Advanced ATP / Logistics Execution. Once POD is confirmed, the system triggers GIT ‚Üí COGS accounting:

  • Credit GIT
  • Debit COGS

5. Billing & Revenue Recognition
Billing document is created in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Billing.

Accounting entries:

  • Debit Trade Receivables
  • Credit Revenue

Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) ensures revenue is recognized only after POD.

entry.content:
Dear All

In view of our development task,  we are using SOAP API ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest_In to get the material data from external system(non SAP).

First BC set MDGM_MDG_MATERIAL_CR_SOAP_09 activated and CR types MATL0I , MATL0U created, also decision tables configured.   Next SOAMANAGER and DRFIMG configured. 

Then executed sample payload and able to update the material fields and can see the ProductMDMBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out XML in SXI_MONITOR but   change request not created.

Am i missing anything here?  If so , could some one provide your inputs please.

 

regards

Chandra Kishore.

entry.title: How to Configure South Korea Tax Box Structure VAT01 for Form and File Changes
entry.content:
‰∏Ä. Background and Symptom

The form and files have changed in the General Taxpayer VAT Declaration report for South Korea.

The General Taxpayer VAT Declaration report enables you to generate your General Taxpayer VAT Declaration and fulfill the statutory reporting requirements in South Korea. You generate this report in the Run Statutory Reports app.

The following tax box definitions need to be updated:

  1. Adjust the following tax box numbers:

Old Tax Box Number

New Tax Box Number

Description

10-1

11

Import Payment Incentives of Export Company

20-1

22

VAT-Exempt Amount for Small Personal Business

        2. Create a new tax box as follows:

Tax Box Number

Description

25

Interim Assessment Tax Amount

‰∫å. Prerequisites

This SAP KBA is relevant only for South Korea. Ensure that you have the necessary authorizations as delivered with the Configuration Expert - Business Process Configuration (SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT) business role template.

‰∏â. Solution

You can change the tax box structure definition via the configuration activity Define Enhanced Tax Box Structure (ID 103011). Follow the steps below to modify, delete, and add the required tax groups and tax boxes.

Steps:

  1. Open the configuration activity Define Enhanced Tax Box Structure (ID 103011).
  • In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the activity.
    If you are using the Manage Your Solution app, select the activity under Finance > Statutory Reporting > Tax.
    If you are using the CBC system, select the activity under Accounting > Tax Management > Tax Declaration > Tax Declaration.

        2. Open the coSelect the target country/region.

  • Select ‚ÄúSouth Korea‚Äù as the target country/region.

        3. Copy the tax box structure to a new version.
             To make changes, you must copy the tax box structure as a new version. This ensures that all changes are done in the new                        version of the tax box structure.

  • Select the current tax box structure, and click Copy As.

  • Specify a new Valid From date. Note that the Valid From date should not be the same as other Valid From dates under the same tax box structure type (TaxBoxStTy).

  • Click Copy or press Enter. And press Enter again if a warning message appears.

  • Click Copy All to copy the existing record to this new tax box structure version.

  • Click Save after you copied it. A new record will be displayed under VAT01.

        4. Delete tax boxes.

  • In the new version of the tax box structure, select the Define Tax Boxes (External) tab.
  • Select the following tax boxes:

Tax Box Number

Description

  • Save your changes.

        5. Add new tax boxes.

  • In the new version of the tax box structure, select the Define Tax Boxes (External) tab.

entry.title: Extreme performance problems with new application for Crystal Reports in .Net
entry.content:
Hello there. I'm currently in the process of rebuilding the old print handling of my companies Delphi application. We used to use the native Delphi components from Crystal Reports for it but eventually they stopped working reliably, so i built it new. Printing is now done via a C# application that gets triggered with a .json file and then does the whole printing using the CR SDK.

Now the application is complete, after some confusing hacks to get it to work how we wanted it, and has been rolled out to the first few customers and we are experiencing extreme delays in performance. We are speaking of up to 30 seconds between pressing the print button in our Delphi program and the Preview opening, as well as printjobs without a preview taking up to 10 seconds to be printed.

This seems to vary heavily, but even on my developer machine it takes up to 6-7 seconds to get to the preview. Compared to the previous almost instantaneous process with the native components this is an unacceptable delay. I have been tracking down the performance loss, especially with the customers who experienced up to 30 seconds and more, and found out two very specific sources for the delay.

1: The setting of a printers name in the property ReportDocument.PrintOptions.Printername (Up to 5 Seconds and more)

2: The method ReportDocument.PrintOptions.CopyFrom(), after we modified the PrintOptions. (Up to 20 seconds and more!)

I have googled, read forum posts, compared documentation and tried out a lot of things, but nothing helped. I can barely find anything about this problem at all, which i find insane. Such a huge loss in performance surely must have been noticed by almost anyone using the SDK?

I don't know if i did something wrong in using the SDK, but im basically out of options, so i hope someone here can help me. I'd be happy to supply further information as well as source code if needed

entry.title: Re: Request to Create Separate Intercompany GL Accounts a...
entry.content:
You want to split intercompany postings into separate GL accounts by category:

  • Overheads / Common Costs
  • Rent
  • Trade
  • Expenses on Behalf Of
  • Fund Transfers

This is feasible but requires careful configuration because OBYA only allows one account pair per company code relationship. To achieve multiple accounts, you need additional logic.

Required SAP Configuration Changes

1. Create New GL Accounts
Define separate GL accounts under the intercompany reconciliation group. Ensure each account is marked as reconciliation account type ‚ÄúIntercompany‚Äù and allows automatic clearing.

2. Define Substitution Rules
In Public Cloud, you cannot freely enhance OBYA like in on-premise. Instead, you use Business Rules Framework (BRF+) / SSCUI substitutions to redirect postings to the correct intercompany GL based on:

  • Transaction type
  • Document type
  • Posting key
  • Cost center / account assignment

Example:

If document type = ‚ÄúFund Transfer‚Äù ‚Üí Post to Fund Transfer GL.

If allocation cycle posting ‚Üí Post to Overheads GL.

3. Transaction Tagging
Use Document Type or Posting Key to differentiate transaction categories. Alternatively, configure custom fields (via In-App extensibility) and map them in substitution rules.

4. Automatic Clearing
Ensure each intercompany GL account is flagged for automatic clearing in account master data. Define clearing rules (e.g., by company code, document type) so balances reconcile automatically.

5. Reporting
With separate GLs, you can now run Fiori apps (Intercompany Reconciliation, Balance Sheet, Trial Balance) to see balances by category. This improves visibility and makes reconciliation easier.

entry.title: Re: BTP ABAP SaaS Solution: Custom Field not available in...
entry.content:
Hi Johannes, 

there are two prerequisites for the predefined fields being available in the services.

  1. there needs to be a C-View which is exposed in a service using service definition/service binding
  2. this C-View needs to be also added to the predefined fields enabling object as related view entity (the related view entities array is basically the list of cds views to which the predefined fields are added as view extension when the predefined field enabling is activated)

In your case the predefined fields are only added to the I-View (which I guess is your RAP BO View) as you can see in the predefined fields enabling. So if you also have a service built with service definition/service binding, the exposed CDS View needs to be added, to the PCF enabling file, e.g.

{ 
"viewEntity":"/TCON/C_EMPLOYEE",
"baseObjectAlias":"EMPLOYEE",
"viewExtension":"/TCON/C_EMPLOYEE_EXT"
}

After activation of the enabling, also the extension of the C-view is generated and the fields are available in the services later on.

Hope, this helps and clarifies how predefined fields need to be configured.

Best Regards,
Daniel

entry.title: Re: Mass Creation of Derived roles
entry.content:
1. Create an ECATT script that creates the derived roles, with description and link to parent but without a profile.

Respond from customer:

A regular employee which is responsible for roles & authorizations does not know how to create an ECATT script.

3. Delete all unwanted org level values from your new derived roles with transaction PFCGMASSVAL. (I'm guessing here that you're on a recent SAP version)

Respond from Customer:

Even if an employee would know how to create an ECATT script, this task is too time consuming.

e.g. If only one new mother role has to be set up which has 30 or 100 or 1000 derived roles and the mother role has for example 5 SAP org fields,

=> 150 or 500 or 5000 single changes with pfcgmassval would be required

 To work with PFCGMASSVAL is only useful, if you have to change one or a few authorization values in x roles

but not if you have to change a lot of values in x roles.

entry.title: Re: Copy Company Code: Move Country Template from client...
entry.content: Normally, client 100 should have been created as a copy of client 000 during system setup, so all templates are available. If that wasn‚Äôt done, the cleanest way is to transport the missing country template customizing from 000 to 100. entry.title: Re: Mass Creation of Derived roles
entry.content:
To 1. Create an ECATT script that creates the derived roles, with description and link to parent but without a profile.

Respond from customer:
A regular employee which is responsible for roles & authorizations does not know how to create an ECATT script.

To 3. Delete all unwanted org level values from your new derived roles with transaction PFCGMASSVAL. (I'm guessing here that you're on a recent SAP version)

Respond from Customer:

Even if an employee would know how to create an ECATT script, this task is too time consuming.

e.g. If only one new mother role has to be set up which has 30 or 100 or 1000 derived roles and the mother role has for example 5 SAP org fields,

=> 150 or 500 or 5000 single changes with pfcgmassval would be required

 To work with PFCGMASSVAL is only useful, if you have to change one or a few authorization values in x roles

but not if you have to change a lot of values in x roles.

entry.title: Re: Event mesh design
entry.content:
Hello,

You could have one queue for each of your Applications, which will be subscribed to the topics they are interested. For example, if the topic is: businessobject/<datacenter>

  • And your app is is interested in the information coming from all datacenters you can subscribe to: businessobject/*
  • If another app is interested in only the ones starting with HEC4 then you can subsrcibe to: businessobject/HEC4+
  • If another app is only interested in HEC45, you can subscribe to: businessobject/HEC45

This you can achieve with Event Mesh in Integration Suite, but of course, Advance Event Mesh will give you much more options. For example, you could have one broker in each datacenter and build a mesh of brokers.

Best regards

Javier

entry.title: Re: credit card statement posting in SAP
entry.content:
Good day @BE_JF 

Thank you for your question

Yes, in public cloud, you can import outgoing credit card statements if you handle them as statement data for a clearing account. You should model the card settlement account as a house bank account and import the statement through the bank statement tools. See Import Electronic Account Information and Manual vs. Electronic Bank Statements for more details.

To achieve that make use of the Manage Incoming Payment files app for the importation of your electronic account information, then review and post the statement in Manage Bank Statements. That will enable reconciliation of the credit card clearing account.

Regarding you question on potential additional steps requirement, for basic manual of file based statement import, you do not need a special scope item beyond having the financial bank statement processing capability enable and the right roles assigned to you or other users. see https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/03eabc3f799944598c8e6be95eee9524.html for more details.

If your requirement is to feed employee level corporate card with automatic expense categorisation, then this is not delivered as a core function but you can cover this by an expesnse solution. If your scenario is about digital payment processing and settlement advice, you may requires additional digital payments setup.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Shortening of the depreciation time after impairment
entry.content:
Hello,

I am facing the following issue.
After performing impairment and making changes in the asset master, when I run AW01N again to check depreciation, the depreciation time is shortened. 
For details: 
  • The asset was transferred from Asset Under Construction (AuC) on November 30, 2024.
  • Asset value: 137,441,237
  • Depreciation started on June 1, 2025, useful life of 15 years, using the straight-line method.
  • The original plan was for depreciation to end in 2040.
  • After performing an asset impairment and making changes to the asset master data, when checking in AW01N (Asset Explorer), the planned depreciation end year was shortened by 7 years, now ending in 2033 instead of 2040.
Before making changes in the asset master:
Depreciation tab in asset master (T-code: AS03)
Depreciation key: DS7
Useful life: 5 years

Asset explorer (T-code AW01N)

The transaction of impairment is reflected.

Impairment value: 66,575,549

Depreciation over 15 years from 2025 to 2040

 Making changes in the asset master:

Depreciation key: DS07‚ÜíILI

Useful life: 15 years ‚Üí 14 years and 5 months

Update net book value= 65,494,026 and acquisition value= 70,865,688

Check asset explorer (T-code AW01N)

The depreciation time is shortened. Before being changed, the asset is depreciated from 2025 to 2040 but after being changed, it is depreciated from 2025 to 2033.

I tested 2 assets for the same scenario.

The above asset was transferred from an internal order ‚Üí asset under construction ‚Üí the current asset. 
This issue only occurs with assets transferred from asset under construction, while assets acquired through T-code ABZON are not affected by this issue
 
Has anyone encountered a similar situation? What is the root cause, and is there a way to prevent the depreciation time from being shortened?
Thank you in advance.

entry.title: Accelerate your cloud adoption journey with Cloud Integration Automation service
entry.content:
As many customers adopt SAP Business Suite‚Äîa comprehensive set of integrated solutions combining Cloud ERP with Line of Business (LOB) applications, integration becomes a critical architectural pillar for delivering seamless, end-to-end business processes and unlocking the full potential of the SAP Business Suite.  
 
Typically, integration requires an extensive review of documentation, identification of all relevant components and entities, system landscape, creation of a detailed integration plan and the engagement of the appropriate subject matter experts with multiple reiterations. Altogether, these steps make integration a complex and time-consuming process. 

To address this, the Cloud Integration Automation service creates one consolidated guided workflow that orchestrates every step across the entire integration process. 

While the Cloud Integration Automation Service supports both public and private cloud scenarios, this blog focuses on providing an in-depth look at the public cloud scenarios available and how they can be utilized to accelerate your cloud adoption journey. 

Cloud Integration Automation service: Introduction 

Cloud Integration Automation service is an SAP BTP based integration application that comes with no additional cost that generates guided workflow to integrate SAP cloud solutions to on-premises and other SAP cloud solutions. The guided workflow contains automated tasks and instructions for manual tasks to enable an easy and quick integration configuration. 

Cloud Integration Automation service: Benefits  

Following are the benefits of using Cloud Integration Automation service: 

  • Provides planning capabilities to plan integration 
  • Comes with standardized and intuitive user interface 
  • Accelerates cloud adoption by reducing the overall integration time 
  • Integrated parameter management 
  • Traceability of all activities 

Cloud Integration Automation service: Guided workflow 

Upon subscribing to and utilizing the Cloud Integration Automation service for any supported integration scenario, the application generates a guided workflow that includes all the necessary tasks to complete the integration 

Below are some of the highlights of the workflow 

  • Provides integration entity or component information 
  • Fetch the underlying integration landscape  
  • Offers role-based implementation of each task 
  • Provides automated tasks 
  • Provides step by step manual instructions 
  • Provides integration guidance at each component level 

Cloud Integration Automation service: step-by-step 

Step 1: Select the required integration scenario 

Log in to Cloud Integration Automation service home page and select ‚ÄúPlan for integration‚Äù 

Select the required scenario from the list for e.g. ‚ÄúTravel Expense Processing with SAP Concur Expense Professional(1M1)‚Äù 

Step 2: Generate role-based workflow 

Click on select systems 

Provide system details for each component and click on ‚ÄúGenerate Workflow‚Äù 

Step 3: Assign the tasks to the right experts 

Go to ‚ÄúMy Inbox‚Äù, select ‚ÄúI Agree‚Äù 

Verify the system information and click on ‚ÄúConfirm Systems‚Äù 

Assign the tasks to experts and click on ‚ÄúConfirm Role Assignment‚Äù 

Step 4: Run and monitor the tasks until the completion of integration 

Start implementing each task and click on ‚ÄúTask Completed‚Äù once the task is completed 

You can monitor the tasks by clicking on ‚ÄúScenario Monitoring‚Äù 

Supported public cloud scenarios 

Currently Cloud Integration Automation service supports around 50+ public cloud scenarios for which you can use to generate workflows. Below is the list of supported scenarios. 

  • Travel Expense Processing with SAP Concur Expense Professional (1M1) 
  • Automatic Market Rates Management (1S4)  
  • Payroll Processing with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (1NL)  
  • Credit Agency Integration (1RY)  
  • Customer Payments (1S0)  
  • Digital Payments (1S2)  
  • Opportunity-to-Order with SAP Cloud for Customer (1VP)  
  • Restricted Party Screening with SAP Watch List Screening (1WE) 
  • SAP S/4HANA for Enterprise Contract Management (1XV)  
  • Import Connection setup with SAP Analytics Cloud (1YB)  
  • Digital Payments Sales (1Z1) 
  • External Billing (1Z6)  
  • Logistics with Third-Party Warehouse Management (1ZQ)  
  • External Workforce Procurement via SAP Fieldglass (22K)  
  • Integration of Procurement with External Suppliers (2EJ)  
  • Integration of Sales with External Buyers (2EL) 
  • Integration of Payment Advice with Buyers and Suppliers (2MB)  
  • Guided Buying Capability with SAP Ariba Buying (2NV)  
  • Continuous Control Monitoring with SAP Process Control (2OH)  
  • Integration to SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Enterprise Contract Assembly (2OQ)  
  • International Trade Management with SAP GTS  
  • Key Risk Indicator Monitoring with SAP Risk Management (2U2)  
  • Automated Provisioning via SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (3AB)   
  • Guided Buying for Central Procurement with SAP Ariba Buying (3EN)  
  • Payroll Processing with SAP ERP HCM Payroll (3UP)  
  • Third-Party Shop Floor Execution - Process Industry (3W3)  
  • Third-Party Shop Floor Execution - Discrete Industry (3W4)  
  • Service Order Processing with SAP Field Service Management (49X)  
  • Automation of Source-to-Pay with SAP Business Network (42K)  
  • Automation of Order-to-Invoice with SAP Business Network (4A1)  
  • Workforce Management with SAP Master Data Integration (Inbound)  
  • Setting Up SAP Ariba Buying (4AI)  
  • Contract Management with SAP Ariba Contracts (4AZ)  
  • Contract for Central Procurement with Ariba Contracts (4B0)  
  • Sourcing with SAP Ariba Sourcing (4BL)  
  • SAP Central Invoice Management (4N6)  
  • Central Procurement with SAP Ariba Sourcing (4QN)  
  • Services Procurement with SAP Business Network and SAP Fieldglass (4R2) 
  • Digital Payments Foundation (53V)  
  • ABAP Core Data Services Extraction for SAP Datasphere (53L)  
  • Subscription Management with Sales Billing (57Z)  
  • Subcontracting with SAP Business Network (5I2)   
  • Subscription Management with Convergent Invoicing (5IK)  
  • Automation of Central Procurement Quotes with Ariba Network (5JT)  
  • Real Estate Integration between S/4HANA cloud with C4RE (5VX)  
  • Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (JB1)  
  • MRP Change Request Integration with SAP Business Network (65D)  
  • Solution Order Quotation Management with SAP CPQ (6BV)  
  • Resource Management capability in SAP Project and Resource Management (6JO)  
  • Integrate SAP S/4HCE with SAP Sales and Service Cloud (6KO)  
  • S/4HANA Cloud for Projects, Collaborative Project Management (6JN)  
  • Integration to Icertis for Contract Assembly (6V2) 
  • 3SL Migration Precheck of S/4 - CIAS Connection   

You can find all the scenarios: What is Cloud Integration Automation Service? | SAP Help Portal 

Conclusion 

Supporting over 50+ public cloud integration scenarios, the Cloud Integration Automation service is a powerful, user-friendly framework that generates guided workflows to expedite cloud adoption journey, enhance integration efficiency and lower overall effort.

Related links:

entry.title: Can anyone explain what happened with the login process for SAP sites in 2026
entry.content:
Hi 

I have a private user to login to the community. I have had this user for more than 20 years and it has been inherited from SCN and before that from SDN.

I used to login with a user-id P0000xx (not to be confused with a moderne SAP P-user) and I feel kind of attached to this user-id. It is a part of my identity. 

Now in 2026 I can't login with my old user-id any more, but I found that I can login with my email address and still have access to all my old content - All the way back to the launch of SDN in 2003.
I can't see my old user-id any where in my account setting or user settings. What happened?

It is not just nostalgia because I also have assigned s-users from various customers and i have access to a customer BTP accounts  - with the same email address that is now my new SDN user.

Before there was a clear separation with between my accounts. To login I used my p0000xx for the community, I used my email for BTP and I used s-users for me.sap.com.

When I log into the community with this email and then opens a new tab with BTP or me.sap.com it will automatic sign in (SSO). I haven't seen problems with BTP because I get in with the right account, but in me.sap.com it logs in with my community account which doesn't have access to anything in me.sap.com.

The work around is that I log in to the community with edge and me.sap.com with google chrome. Without the SSO I can still login to me.sap.com with the s-user id.

In me.sap.com I see a message
"Effective Jan 20: UID login will be permanently deactivated; only S-User login will be available (KBA: How to reset an S-User ID Password). Change occurs during CET work hours."
Does this mean that the problem with SSO with my email address will be solved on Jan. 20?

Have I lost my old SDN user id for good? 

... and where is SAP Universal ID in all this?

Best regards
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

PS. My first question in SDN in 2003 was why they had left out all ABAP content from the community. Later ABAP came back in full force, but today I often ask the same question. Today the attack on ABAP is more sneaky. They pretend that RAP is ABAP, but in reality it is EML and odata - and it has very little to do with ABAP.

entry.title: Setting the Default Kerberos Credential in MacBook Credential Cache
entry.content:
This blog solves an issue that can occur when a MacBook holds more than one Kerberos Token for the device user, and the so-called Default or Primary Kerberos Token is not the one that SAP Secure Login Client needs to perform SSO over SAPGUI to an SAP system. There are two manual solutions, and also an automated solution using a script and a plist file.

Because most SAP experts, and actually very many IT experts, often have a limited understanding of how Kerberos works, and/or of how Kerberos works for SSO over SAPGUI, so this blog provides the long story so as to hopefully show why the solutions are sometimes needed, and how these solutions work.

 

Intro and Context

In many organisations, for years the main directory-based Identity Service has been Microsoft Active Directory ("AD") - and most likely AD will continue to be important for many years to come.

In particular, many services in organisations use AD-based Kerberos as the solution enabling SSO (Single Sign-On) - for example, SAPGUI clients such as SAPGUI for Java for MacBook and SAPGUI for Windows, with the help of the SAP Secure Login Client utility app, can use a user's AD-based Kerberos Token to enable SSO SAPGUI sessions.

In the screenshot, replaced the actual Kerberos Token with a green rectangle - let's give it an imaginary identity though for this blog's imaginary user, Marmot Marmotsson, who is the AD-user: MARMOT@AD.BURROW (...the "AD.BURROW" part is called the Kerberos Realm).

When you login to your organisation-managed device - or when you login to your organisation's network; and assuming that your organisation is running a Kerberos server (often called "KDC"), and assuming that the Kerberos server bases its distribution of Kerberos Tokens for users defined in the organisations Active Directory... then the Kerberos server will send the logged-in user a Kerberos TGT ("Kerberos Ticket Granting Token", often abbreviated to "Kerberos Token"). This Kerberos Token is then squirreled away in a wee store on your device called the (Kerberos) Credentials Cache.

On a MacBook, there are two main methods for viewing the Kerberos Tokens in the Credentials Cache. One method is to open the system app called Ticket Viewer, e.g. via Spotlight (<command> + <space-bar>) then typing "ticket" and double-clicking on Ticket Viewer:

Yous have all been paying attention so you know that the green rectangle in this screenshot represents the Kerberos Token for MARMOT@AD.BURROW üòÑ.

The other method is to open a Terminal and use the 'klist' utility, more on that method later. For now, we are just noting that our human - or at least, mammalian - user Marmot Marmotsson has a relevant Kerberos Token for their AD-based user.

So now the user opens their SAPGUI for Java for MacBook app ("SAPGUI app"), where typically there is a list (or lists, if multiple workspaces) of Connection Items for connecting to SAP systems. In case Kerberos has been implemented properly generally, and in particular for SAP systems (a config-topic not considered in this blog), then each SAP system will have been defined in Active Directory as a so-called SPN ("Service Principal Name"), and if you view the details of a relevant Connection Item, under tab "Security", you should find that "Enable Secure Network Connection" checkbox is ticked (i.e. in ON-state), and also you should find the SAP system's SPN identifier prefixed by "p:CN=" under "SNC Name", and in case of Kerberos usage, one of the radiobutton choices "Authentication" or "Max. Available" has been chosen:

If you like, you can imagine that the screenshot shows the details for SAP system "DDD", which has, say, an SPN called SAPServiceDDD defined in Active Directory.

Now when the user e.g. double-clicks on the Connection Item in the relevant Workspace in their SAPGUI app to open a new SAPGUI session on the SAP system, what happens is that the SAPGUI app realises there is a possibility to perform an SSO logon (given the details of the Connection Item shown above), so it asks a separate client app on MacBook, called SAP Secure Login Client ("SLC"), to handle the authentication steps.

Assuming the SAP Secure Login Client has discovered the Default Kerberos Token for the user on the MacBook (usually it succeeds if such a Token exists), SLC essentially says to the Kerberos server's TGS ("Ticket Granting Service"): "well, I have this Ticket Granting Token on behalf of (say) MARMOT@AD.BURROW - so, for the SPN called SAPServiceDDD, please grant me a ticket!". So this is granted, and as a result the SAP System DDD (i.e. the "service" defined by that SPN) allows the user to logon.

[There is typically user-mapping configuration done in the target SAP System to relate each ADuser@Realm ticket to an SAP User ID - you would typically find this info in tcode SU01 (go to tab SNC for some user): the SAP User (say, MARMOTDD) has an SNC Name consisting of the prefix "p:CN=" and then the MARMOT@AD.BURROW (ADuser@Realm) text].

So the result is that the user is logged in to their SAPGUI session, and a message at the bottom of the SAPGUI screen informs you of the SSO success:

 

In this screenshot, the magenta rectangle covers the SAP system-client number and the SAP User ID for that system-client, while the green rectangle covers the MARMOT@AD.BURROW identifier.

So, that's how SSO for SAPGUI using Kerberos happens, when all the various config is correct on: the SAP system itself, the Active Directory, the KDC, the MacBook, the SAPGUI app, and the SAP Secure Login Client. "Easy... what could possibly go wrong?!" üòÇ... well, we will see how one innocent change to the way MacBook receives and stores Kerberos Tokens, introduced to improve the SSO-for-browsers user-experiences, can inadvertently break this SSO for SAPGUI workflow...

 

More Than One Kerberos Token

Nowadays one of the main use cases for SSO in organisations is to authenticate to various web services using a browser. For example, it's quite common that for SAP Fiori Launchpads, the authentication is done via Microsoft Entra ID (which used to be called Azure Active Directory). There are of course other companies providing similar authentication services, but we will follow our Entra ID example.

So this is fine, but: Entra ID has its own separate Kerberos Realm, so it does not itself use the Kerberos Token supplied by our (on-premise) Kerberos server for Realm AD.BURROW; so for the MacBook users in our organisation it means that - per browser session- the user would have to login (via Entra ID) to some web service such as a Fiori Launchpad i.e. specifying username and password, and maybe also using (say) the Microsoft Authenticator mobile app to perform a 2FA manual login. Which is not really SSO anymore, when the user has to do these extra manual logins in addition to their initial device or network login.

So our MacBook and Identity Management teams came up with a good idea: a certain Microsoft service for MacBook gets installed and configured on the local device (we skip the details, other than to say that this service is Microsoft Azure-centric); then when the user logs in to their device, the service can go and fetch (via Azure) two Kerberos Tokens (even if the device isn't currently on the organisation's "on-premise" network): first, a Kerberos Token for the Entra ID user, let's call it:

username@example.com@KERBEROS.MICROSOFTONLINE.COM

The Realm here is the actual Realm used by Entra ID to provide Kerberos. And this Azure-supplied Kerberos Token becomes - on the MacBook device - the Default Token in the Credentials Cache.

In addition, the old-school Kerberos Token for (say) the AD.BURROW Realm is fetched,  via integrations between Azure and our on-premise Active Directory. This Token is also stored in the Credentials Cache, though it is just an "ordinary" Token (and specifically not the Default Token). Ticket Viewer shows both Tokens in the Cache:

Now, this is generally a good thing - for the web services that prefer Entra ID to handle authentication, the browsers (Safari, Chrome, Edge tested) are able to ask the MacBook for the username@example.com@KERBEROS.MICROSOFTONLINE.COM Ticket Granting Token stored in the local Credentials Cache, and so when the user goes to, e.g. some SAP Fiori Launchpad* or some Jira Project page belonging to the organisation, SSO happens (via the Azure-based Kerberos server's TGS, and so on) and the user doesn't need to do manual login to those websites. So that's a real improvement in the users working lives.

[*Note that for services located on your on-premise network which are not configured for public Internet access, you still need to be yourself connected to the on-premise network to access those services, e.g. on the office LAN or via a VPN connection - even if you have SSO working. Remember kids: SSO automates login workflows, but it doesn't create its own "additional" VPN tunnel through your firewall... maybe you already know this, but in my experience many people don't yet know this, so FYR].

The only downside to having these two Kerberos Tokens, where the Token for the AD.BURROW Realm isn't the Default Token, is that, well, SSO for SAPGUI doesn't work in this scenario anymore (though this blog will later explain how to get it working again). The reason for failure is that SAP Secure Login Client is only aware of the Default Token in the local Credentials Cache, so it finds only the Token for KERBEROS.MICROSOFTONLINE.COM - but because this Azure-based Kerberos server doesn't know anything about the SPN (say) SAPServiceDDD defined within an entirely different Kerberos Realm (and what the server does not know, it certainly will not trust), so it is not going to be able to grant a Ticket for the relevant SAP Service (e.g. SAP System DDD)... and so the logon attempt to DDD over SAPGUI fails, probably with the following error message:

Well, that's annoying. So we need solutions which allow us to keep both Kerberos Tokens in the local Credential Cache, but for the Default Token to be the one for the on-premise, AD-based Kerberos Realm.

Below we describe three solutions. I have tested that they work, including testing that for the websites using the Azure-based Kerberos Token, those continue to work even when that Azure-based Kerberos Token loses its "Default" status in the local Credentials Cache. Disclaimer: if these solutions don't work for you, then you will need to find your own solutions, as I don't run any Helpdesk in my spare time, and won't in future either üòÇ .

[A fourth possible solution would be if the Microsoft service on the MacBook could do the needed swapping of the Default Token at fetch-and-store-time, but as I have solved the issue on client-device side already using the below solutions, so I haven't investigated this possibility].

It's a good idea to close SAP Secure Login Client and close SAPGUI for Java for MacBook before applying any of the manual solutions, to ensure that old Token info isn't left in the caches of these apps. One way is to right-click on their respective icons in the Dock, and choose "Quit". Or: in the top menu of the SAPGUI app, choose SAPGUI -> Quit SAPGUI; and in the wee icon in the right-hand side of MacBook top menu bar, for SAP Secure Login Client (white tick on blue diamond), click on the icon and choose Quit SAP Secure Login Client.

 

Solution 1 - Use Ticket Viewer to Change Default Token

Open Ticket Viewer - e.g. via Spotlight (<command> + <space-bar>) then typing "ticket" and double-clicking on Ticket Viewer - then click on the Token you want to set as the Default Token so that it is highlighted (blue background denotes highlighted item). In our example, we highlight the Token for AD.BURROW ...Then click on the button called "Set as Default":

And, well... that's all you need to do!

Ticket Viewer doesn't tell you that this action has succeeded, and has no marker identifying the current Default Token in the list, but I have tested that the button works fine.

Now you can open SAPGUI app and logon via SSO using in our AD-based Kerberos Token (SAPGUI app will open SAP Secure Login Client when needed).

"So you wrote this long blog just to tell us about such a simple solution??" ...well, it's simple enough once you realise that it's a solution, but realising what to do is tricky unless you have understood the root cause of the issue. The good thing about this solution using Ticket Viewer is it is quite easy to use. The disadvantage is that each user needs to remember to do this manual solution every time they login to their device, and before they open the SAPGUI app. Which is why I developed a better solution ("Solution 3", below in this blog) that doesn't require the users to implement this Ticket Viewer solution. Though the manual solution remains as a good fallback option in case a more complex solution doesn't work.

During the research for a better solution, I found an interim solution ("Solution 2" below) that i might use myself, but most users wouldn't use - anyway the next section describes this Terminal app solution...

 

Solution 2 - Terminal app, klist, and kswitcher

Because I wanted to automate the solution that uses Ticket Viewer, well, one way to do that is to first work out what happens at command-line level when a user presses the "Set as Default" button in the Ticket Viewer app (and once this is known, use a script and config file to further automate). So I found the relevant commands... to use them, open the Terminal app... the first one is:

klist

This command displays the current Default Token from the Credentials Cache. But we would like to see a list of all Kerberos Tokens in the cache, for that we should use:

klist -l

[The option is the lowercase "L", abbreviation of "list-all", and not the numeral "1"].

In the results command, the current Default Token is denoted by the relevant item having an asterisk character '*' as the first string at the start of its line, shown in this heavily redacted screenshot in the magenta box:

 

To change the default, the easy way is to use the command:

kswitch -i

["i" for "interactive"].

This lists all the Tokens in the cache with line numbers, and asks you to choose the line number of the Token you want to be set as default. So you choose the number, e.g. of the line for AD.BURROW Token in our blog example - so that is line 2 from the above screenshot - and then you can check (using 'klist -l' again) that the relevant Token was indeed set. Now you can open SAPGUI app and logon to SAP using SSO.

 

Solution 3 - A script and a plist file

This works for me just fine - feel free to base your own solutions on my templates, but remember kids, I am not going to offer any debug help if this doesn't work for you.

So the idea is to have a script, which runs at user login to the MacBook, and the script assumes that during the first 30 seconds after user login, the computer retrieves some Kerberos Tokens and sets the Azure-based Token as Default - so that when the script discovers those Tokens, it can if needed set the AD-based Token to be Default.

[The reason I mention this assumption, is that it may not be true in your organisation. For example, it could be that all the Kerberos Tokens for your user+device combination are only fetched later, e.g. once the user connects to a VPN - in such a case, you would need some way of running this script once some system or program event is recognised, or by some other method like a wee GUI app or whatever. And since that "delayed fetch"-scenario doesn't apply to me in my organisation, I haven't researched the details of that scenario at all. Probably it's doable though, wishing yous good luck with that].

To enable the script to run at login, we define a plist file, which is an XML file. Here is an example file, called com.example.org.kswitcher.plist

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">

<plist version="1.0">
    <dict>
        <key>Label</key>
        <string>com.example.org.kswitcher</string>
        <key>LimitLoadToSessionType</key>
        <array>
            <string>Aqua</string>
        </array>
	    <key>Program</key>
	    <string>/Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitcher.zsh</string>
        <key>RunAtLoad</key>
        <true/>
    </dict>
</plist>

 

It's important to make sure that the Label string matches the filename minus the ".plist" part. [If you don't make them match properly, the plist does nothing]. So in our case the correct string is com.example.org.kswitcher

The LimitLoadToSessionType key with value "Aqua" just ensures that this plist is only "active" for GUI-based user login sessions (i.e. the typical situation, not remote SSH login). Then the Program key specifies where our special custom-built kswitcher.zsh script is located. And the RunAtLoad key just means that the specified Program should run when the user logs in.

So for the relevant user, this plist file goes in their home directory:

~/Library/LaunchAgents

...the "~" means the home directory of the current user (so the target LaunchAgents directory is in the Library directory of the user, and not in the Library directory of the device).

Ok, so the plist file is in the right place - being in the user's LaunchAgents directory, the plist will be run next time the user logs in to their device. Now what about the kswitcher.zsh script that the plist will run? First you create the directory that matches where the plist will look for the script, so for example:

mkdir -p /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin

Then you put the script in that subdirectory, and change the permissions of the script so that any logged-in user can run it, for example:

chmod 775 /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitcher.zsh

Here is the template for kswitcher.zsh - obviously you would swap in your own Realm in case it is not the same as in the blog example (where we use AD.BURROW). BTW I am not saying this is the best code ever, only that it worked well enough for me - feel free to develop your own version from any clues in this script...

#!/bin/zsh
###################################################################
# dylan drummond, helsinki                                        #
# 26.11.2025 - 12.01.2026 (dd.mm.yyyy)                            #
# Licensed under: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/2.5/ #
###################################################################

###################################################################
# This script switches the default Kerberos credentials to be     #
# those for the AD.BURROW realm, so that Secure Login Client      #
# picks up the correct Kerberos Token.                            #
###################################################################

# Add a log-entry:
date >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
echo "kswitcher script running..." >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
# counter=0

# At interval of 0.5 seconds (half a second), up to around 30 seconds from login, check to see if kswitch can be done:
repeat 60 {
# counter=$((counter+1))
# date >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
# echo "klist iteration: " $counter >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog

# Get the output of 'klist -l'
  OURKLISTL="$(klist -l)"
  ADSTR="$(echo $OURKLISTL | grep AD.BURROW)"
  ADTOKEN="$(echo $ADSTR | awk '{print $1}')"

# If empty, wait 0.5 seconds before retry (use 'continue' to skip to next loop iteration):
  if [ -z $ADTOKEN ]
  then   
    sleep 0.5 
    continue
  fi

# We check whether the default Kerberos Token is already the AD-based one, 
# i.e. if the ADTOKEN contains an asterisk instead of the actual Kerberos Token.
# In that case there is nothing to do so we can exit 0 i.e. exit with success return code...
  if [ "$ADTOKEN" = "*" ]
  then   
    date >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
    echo "Nothing to do as AD.BURROW credentials are already the default... Bye!" >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
    exit 0
  fi

# We assume that if we got to this point, we have the string matching the relevant credential in ADTOKEN, 
# ...because if the Kerberos Token is not the default, that Token will be the first string retrieved into ADTOKEN.
# So we can kswitch:
  kswitch --principal=$ADTOKEN

# We need to check that this has worked:
  if [ $? -ne 0 ]
  then   
    date >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
    echo "Before SAPGUI usage: Open Ticket Viewer app from Spotlight and set AD.BURROW Token as default using the button!" \
     >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
    exit 1
  fi
  date >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
  echo "kswitcher ran successfully!" >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
  exit 0

}
# Ended repeat loop

#If we got through that repeat loop, that should mean no AD.BURROW Token was found via 'klist -l':
date >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog
echo "No Kerberos Token found for Realm AD.BURROW, so we cannot set non-existent token to be default credential." >> /Users/Shared/macscripts/userlogin/kswitchlog

 

Once you have the automated solution set up (plist and script in correct locations and file permissions set), so you can log out of your MacBook, then login again and check if the solution works e.g. from the logfile, before opening SAPGUI app and unit-testing. You can see from the template that the script runs for up to 30 seconds and uses some kind of primitive Watcher-pattern, checking every half a second for Kerberos Tokens - and if they are found, attempting to kswitch the relevant Token to be the Default Token:

kswitch --principal=$ADTOKEN

[Note the two hyphens before "principal", as this option specified using the full name of the option. Unlike in Solution 2, we don't use 'kswitch -i', because in the script we want to avoid making the user interactively choose a Default Token].

So, good luck if you choose to use this Solution 3 with plist and script as a way to automate Solution 1 using Ticket Viewer. If it doesn't work, good luck in your attempts to make it work; but remember that you can always fall back to using Ticket Viewer and the "Set as Default" button as a manual solution. Anyway remember to ensure that both SAPGUI app and SAP Secure Login Client are closed until some solution has been applied, so that when they are opened they will use the new Default Token that you set.

Although I have tested that this template version of the script runs ok (no syntax errors), in reality I have no such Kerberos Token for the imaginary AD.BURROW Realm, so it wasn't a very comprehensive test: the logfile recorded an entry about no such Token for that Realm found, so the expected results matched the actual results üòÇ...however, this template was made by replacing (in a copy of the original script) the actual Realm used in my organisation, and I have tested that original script successfully: it's working every day I login to my device, thanks to the plist that ensures the original script runs at login.

Also you can see some commented-out commands that I used when building and testing the script (so I could find out roughly how many seconds my device took to fetch the Kerberos Tokens and put them in the Credentials Cache - usually about 5 seconds). Left them in the script as comments, as a reference in case you want to do similar logging of the loop iterations.

entry.title: Re: Is it applicable to convert Aging Report into RAP ?
entry.content:
Even if I'm not yet a RAP expert I think it is right to say that the database selections and the looping on internal tables will be very similar in RAP compared to classic abap, so  a transition to RAP will not improve performance.

It is not clear what is meant when you say "each raw material is checked if it's existed between 2 dates". I expect it involves select from mbew, mkpf and mseg and that can be a heavy job.

If you are in an on-premise environment with SAP GUI you can performe a runtime analysis (transaction SAT) to see which parts of the program costs most time?

As this is based on historical data that will not change, you may attach the problem with a different approach.

For example:
Make a version of the program that calculates the result not for current month, but for the previous 11 month and save the result in a database table. Run this program in a nightly background job.
Make a version off the program that only runs with the current month data and then combine it with the saved result for the previous 11 months. This would then the program the users run in foreground.

Best Regards
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: Re: Help needed for a custom POD plugin
entry.content:
Hey @Ruudvandeven ,
on my side your question is not so clear, but i will give you my 2cents.

i would recommend you to follow this guide - created by Saint Manoel Costa -  HERE. 

This is for BAS, but it's basically the way to understand how is the process to create and deploy a new plugin.
His guide is referring on standard core plugin extensions, in your way you should develop a pod plugin extensions.

This is the procedure where you deploy an application inside SAP BTP, but your BTP requires credits (cpea? i dont remember the name). There is also a "new way" that refer to upload directly inside SAP DM as zip and not requires cpea credits.

With this second chance, you can develop inside VS/BAS and then create the zip and upload directly from SAP DM (inside POD Designer - Extensions 

).

You just need to know how the structure should be.

Also, you can't test your plugin from vscode (the standard core plugin extensions for sure), i mean maybe there could be some way to work in local (with proxies or others) but from standard point of view if you want to test your code you have to deploy in BAS/DM and check there --> but i am not so skilled to try to find a solution.

I hope it helps,
M.
